Award.AwardTitle: CIF:Medium:Collaborative Research: Understanding and Managing Interference in Communication Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ubiquity of wireless devices and services and the ever increasing bandwidth demand make it imperative to improve spectrum utilization. Key to improving spectrum efficiency in a multi-user networks is understanding and managing interference. This collaborative project studies the phenomenon of interference in communication networks and develops a theoretical foundation on how to deal with interference under realistic operating conditions. The study addresses several long-standing open problems; solutions to those problems should collectively advance our understanding on interference and provide guidance on the design of future wireless networks.

This project pursues a broad range of topics that are of great theoretical and practical significance. Conventional wisdom suggests that, since interference has structure that is not present in thermal noise, this structure should be exploited by transceivers. On the other hand, there are situations where interference can be essentially ignored without compromising system throughput, as evidenced by recent breakthroughs in the study of the sum-rate capacity of Gaussian interference channels. This project demonstrates that there are different regimes for interference management and provide means of analysis for various multi-user communication systems. The transformative nature of this project lies in its ambitious goal of establishing a solid theoretical foundation on how interference should be dealt with in complex networks, and in providing guidance on system designs that achieve optimal performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ubiquity of wireless devices and services leads to the ever increasing bandwidth demand, which makes it imperative to improve spectrum utilization. As wireless users share the same open medium, their transmissions inevitably interfere to each other. Key to improving spectrum efficiency in a multi-user network is a better understanding of the impact of interference as well as a more prudent approach in managing interference. This collaborative project studies the phenomenon of interference in communication networks and develops a theoretical foundation on how to deal with interference under realistic operating conditions.

The project successfully addressed several long-standing open problems that pertain to the effect of interference on the performance of communication networks. Studies conducted under this project have led to some surprising results that put a completely new perspective on how interference ought to be handled in real communication systems. For example, several of the archival papers as a result of this work pointed to cases where interference may be best ignored – system performance is actually optimized when interference is simply treated as noise. This provides a concrete theoretical foundation to some of the common practices in communication system design and leads to new insight on how to approach interference management for some emerging applications.

In addition to a number of archival publications – all published in the top journal in this area, a peer-reviewed monograph has also been published that provides an up-to-date overview in this important field. It is expected to bring even greater awareness to this issue of interference and stimulate broader participation from the research community. Finally, a working software radio has been developed that exhibits robust performance under various interference scenarios; this working software radio provides a great test-bed for validating further research results in this and related research areas.
